wikipedia_page.main: William Cosmo Monkhouse (18 March 1840 – 20 July 1901) was a British poet and critic.

response: *1901 – William Cosmo Monkhouse, English poet and critic (b. 1840)
*1840 – William Cosmo Monkhouse, English poet and critic (d. 1901)
A rhyme by William Cosmo Monkhouse:
*July 20 – William Cosmo Monkhouse, English poet and critic (born 1840)

His most commercially rewarding novel was Diana of the Crossways, published in 1885, which attracted notice because of its relationship to real-life events involving Caroline Norton and Lord Melbourne. Margaret Harris explains that "like many of Meredith's novels, Diana contains commentary on the aims and techniques of fiction, made particularly potent by Diana's being herself a novelist dedicated to 'reading the inner as well as exhibiting the outer'". George Gissing wrote to his brother, "By hook or crook, get hold of Diana of the Crossways. The book is right glorious. Shakespeare in modern English", and William Cosmo Monkhouse wrote in the Saturday Review that "amongst all his intellectual and literary feats, Mr Meredith has, perhaps, never accomplished one more striking".Quoted in Stevenson, The Ordeal of George Meredith, p. 259. Diana was his first book to make an impression in America.Richard Burton, Masters of the English Novel, Frankfurt: Outlook, 2019, p. 160.

Others with links to Skegness include the poet and art critic William Cosmo Monkhouse (born 1840), who died in the town in 1901,Austin Dobson, revised by Sayoni Basu, "Monkhouse, William Cosmo", The Oxford Dictionary of National Biography (online ed., Oxford University Press, September 2004). Retrieved 1 July 2020. and the novelist Vernon Scannell (died 2007), who was born there in 1922.Alan Brownjohn, "Scannell, Vernon [real name John Vernon Bain]", The Oxford Dictionary of National Biography (online ed., Oxford University Press, January 2011). Retrieved 1 July 2020. The former tabloid editor Neil Wallis started his journalistic career at the Skegness Standard in the 1960s.Ian Burrell, "Fleet Street's 'Wolfman': Hardened Hack with a Hotline to the Met", The Independent, 15 July 2011. Retrieved 29 July 2011. . Reginald J. G. Dutton (1886–1970), who created the shorthand Dutton Speedwords, for some time chaired Skegness Urban District Council.Kime (1986), pp. 119, 125. For the dates of birth and death, see John Kennaway, "Dutton Speedwords: Background and Purpose" (University of East Anglia). Retrieved 1 July 2020. . The naval officer Sir Guy Grantham was born in the town in 1900,John Winton, "Grantham, Sir Guy", The Oxford Dictionary of National Biography (online ed., Oxford University Press, September 2004). Retrieved 1 July 2020. as was the seaman Jesse Handsley, who served on Scott's first Antarctic Expedition;"Unveiling of the Jesse Handsley Tribute Board", Skegness Town Council, March 2016. Retrieved 3 July 2020. . Kingsmill Bates (1916–2006) retired to Skegness."Captain Kingsmill Bates", The Times (London), 18 May 2006, p. 62. The chess champion and educator John Littlewood (1931–2009) taught at the grammar school."John Littlewood", The Times (London), 22 September 2009, p. 59.
